dt: {bc}to call forth or draw out (something, such as information or a response)
{bc}to draw forth or bring out (something {d_link|latent|latent:1} or {d_link|potential|potential:1})

pt: {sc}educe{/sc} {sc}evoke{/sc} {sc}elicit{/sc} {sc}extract{/sc} {sc}extort{/sc} mean to draw out something hidden, latent, or reserved. {sc}educe{/sc} implies the bringing out of something potential or latent.
{sc}evoke{/sc} implies a strong stimulus that arouses an emotion or an interest or recalls an image or memory.
{sc}elicit{/sc} usually implies some effort or skill in drawing forth a response.
{sc}extract{/sc} implies the use of force or pressure in obtaining answers or information.
{sc}extort{/sc} suggests a wringing or wresting from one who resists strongly.

pt.t: {it}extorted{/it} their cooperation by threatening to inform

quotes.t: If ever there was a two-way pleasure street, it's the delight a baby takes in being tickled and the joy the parent experiences in the tumble of laughter it {qword}elicits{/qword}.

In a wild, captive wolf that is not socialized to man, approach will {qword}elicit{/qword} flight and, if the wolf is cornered, a defensive reaction may be triggered, which is termed the critical-distance reaction.

Gingrich {qword}elicits{/qword} perhaps the greatest sympathy when he talks about the challenge of graduating from a rabble-rousing backbencher in the House minority to presiding over (and trying to control) the first Republican majority in 40 years.

et: Latin {it}elicitus{/it}, past participle of {it}elicere{/it}, from {it}e-{/it} + {it}lacere{/it} to allure
shortdef: to call forth or draw out (something, such as information or a response)
to draw forth or bring out (something latent or potential)
